SEC. 4. NONDIVISIBLE LOAD PROCEEDING. Section 127 of title 23, United States Code, is amended to include a proceeding initiated by the Secretary to determine the meaning of 'vehicles and loads which cannot be easily dismantled or divided'. Final regulations must be issued within 270 days and apply to all loads on the National Highway System. States may establish additional requirements as long as they are not inconsistent with these regulations. The policy of this title is to promote conformity with Interstate weight limits for the benefit and safety of all motorists. Interstate weight limits include the 80,000 pound gross vehicle weight limitation, single axle weight limitation, tandem axle weight limitation, and overall maximum gross weight on a group of consecutive axles. SEC. 5. WEIGHT LIMITATIONS. Title 23, United States Code, is amended to include new section 127a regarding gross vehicle weight and axle loading limitations on non-Interstate highways on the national highway system. The limitations set by State statute as of January 1, 1994, will apply to vehicles and combinations on non-Interstate highways, with exceptions outlined in subsection (c). The Secretary will determine and publish State weight limitations for non-Interstate highways on the National Highway System as of January 1, 1994. Operations not conforming to these limitations will be listed. The Secretary will publish a final list of operations that do not conform to State weight limitations for non-Interstate highways on the National Highway System before January 1, 1994. All vehicles or combinations on this list must adhere to specific designations in force in a State. The limitations established by subsection (a) apply to new designations on the National Highway System and non-Interstate highways. States can reduce weight limitations on existing non-Interstate highways. Interstate weight limits are defined as 80,000 pounds gross vehicle weight, 20,000 pounds single axle weight, and 34,000 pounds.
